   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female with a significant history of obstructive lung disease and
   now has evolved respiratory failure in the setting of what is likely
   aspiration event and mucus plugging. She has had ICU course complicated
   by significant hypotension and PTX at the time of CVL placement.  She
   does have significant changes in her ECG in the setting of normal
   enzymes but does represent change from previous.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Likely aspiration and mucus plugging in the
   setting of severe background lung disease.  This is supported by
   minimal resistance on the ventilator and capacity to tolerate RR=20
   with minimal autopeep.
   -AC support, weaned fi02 last night in the setting of elevated PaO2
   -NPO and OGT to suction to prevent furthur aspiration
   -Goal PCO2=55-60
   -consider PE as etiology for initial hypoxia interesting given deep
   t-wave inversion but clinical scenario is with significant alternative
   explanations, low CVP and primary bronchospasm noted with event.
   -Will start coverage with Vanco/Zosyn
   -Sputum culture to be sent
   -Will check CK/Troponin but so far negative
   2)Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Acute Exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
 xopenex and ipratropium, suspect that
   patient should not get albuterol and xopenex at the same time
   -No systemic steroids at this time as bronchospasm does seem to be
   improved.
    3)Shock-Septic or Hypovolemic
   -CVP is reasonably low
   -She may have a component of neuropathic contribution but is not
   hypotensive at baseline
   -No evidence of acute MI to suggest cardiogenic shock and CVP is low
   -PE raised as possibility but it does appear to be a vasodilatory shock
   state and less likely obstructive, will get echo this morning to rule
   out right heart strain
   -This may be SIRS in the setting of aspiration pneumonitis
   -move CVP to goal of 12
   -Continue with Levophed and hope to wean with continued volume
   repletion
   -Will work to wean sedation as possible as may be a contributor to
   hypotension
   -ECHO to f/u if quick response is not seen
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Paitent with A-fib suggested on ECG and telemetry
   -Will consider cardioversion if persistent hypotension seen and not
   able to be tolerated with pressor support
   -ECG changes may well be demand ischemia and will follow enzymes which
   are negative to date.
   -Will continue Digoxin as patient transiently in sinus rhythm
    5)Pneumonthorax-
   -Chest tube in place, maintain suction
   -Currently with small leak noted
   -Minimal drainage
   - continued chest tube while on postive pressure ventilation and until
   air appears to have drained from chest tube completely
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram today
   .
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.  Also
   stool occult positive.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated
   - nutrition consult
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   .
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - follow gastroenterology recommendations
   .
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   .
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers of xopenex and ipratropium
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   .
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete
   electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: SC  heparin
   .
   Code: Full code
   .
   Communication: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 849**] Daughter [**Known firstname 341**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 850**].  Alternate is son
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 851**].
   .
   Disposition: ICU care for now

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and atrial arrhythmia. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress, recurrent coffee ground emesis, and melena. The patient underwent intubation and subclavian line placement, but developed a pneumothorax. She required pressors to maintain blood pressure and showed signs of hypotension and shock.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several factors. She has respiratory failure likely due to aspiration and mucus plugging, exacerbated by severe underlying lung disease. There is also evidence of COPD exacerbation, which requires bronchodilators. The patient may be experiencing septic or hypovolemic shock, and there is suspicion of gastrointestinal bleeding. She has atrial fibrillation, and there are EKG changes suggestive of ischemia in the coronary arteries. Additionally, the patient has gastroparesis, chronic abdominal pain, chronic blood loss anemia, and compression fractures in the thoracic spine.

The patient is currently on multiple medications, including norepinephrine, midazolam, fentanyl, piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin, and heparin. She is NPO (nothing by mouth) with an NG tube in place. Her vital signs are stable, but she remains intubated and sedated. The

   Assessment and Plan
   66 yo female with a significant history of obstructive lung disease and
   now has evolved respiratory failure in the setting of what is likely
   aspiration event and mucus plugging. She has had ICU course complicated
   by significant hypotension and PTX at the time of CVL placement.  She
   does have significant changes in her ECG in the setting of normal
   enzymes but does represent change from previous.
    1)Respiratory Failure-Likely aspiration and mucus plugging in the
   setting of severe background lung disease.  This is supported by
   minimal resistance on the ventilator and capacity to tolerate RR=20
   with minimal autopeep.
   -AC support, weaned fi02 last night in the setting of elevated PaO2
   -NPO and OGT to suction to prevent furthur aspiration
   -Goal PCO2=55-60
   -consider PE as etiology for initial hypoxia interesting given deep
   t-wave inversion but clinical scenario is with significant alternative
   explanations, low CVP and primary bronchospasm noted with event.
   -Will start coverage with Vanco/Zosyn
   -Sputum culture to be sent
   -Will check CK/Troponin but so far negative
   2)Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease with Acute Exacerbation-
   -Continue with bronchodilators
 xopenex and ipratropium, suspect that
   patient should not get albuterol and xopenex at the same time
   -No systemic steroids at this time as bronchospasm does seem to be
   improved.
    3)Shock-Septic or Hypovolemic
   -CVP is reasonably low
   -She may have a component of neuropathic contribution but is not
   hypotensive at baseline
   -No evidence of acute MI to suggest cardiogenic shock and CVP is low
   -PE raised as possibility but it does appear to be a vasodilatory shock
   state and less likely obstructive, will get echo this morning to rule
   out right heart strain
   -This may be SIRS in the setting of aspiration pneumonitis
   -move CVP to goal of 12
   -Continue with Levophed and hope to wean with continued volume
   repletion
   -Will work to wean sedation as possible as may be a contributor to
   hypotension
   -ECHO to f/u if quick response is not seen
   4)Atrial Fibrillation-
   -Paitent with A-fib suggested on ECG and telemetry
   -Will consider cardioversion if persistent hypotension seen and not
   able to be tolerated with pressor support
   -ECG changes may well be demand ischemia and will follow enzymes which
   are negative to date.
   -Will continue Digoxin as patient transiently in sinus rhythm
    5)Pneumonthorax-
   -Chest tube in place, maintain suction
   -Currently with small leak noted
   -Minimal drainage
   - continued chest tube while on postive pressure ventilation and until
   air appears to have drained from chest tube completely
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram today
   .
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.  Also
   stool occult positive.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross
   - currently intubated, sedated
   - nutrition consult
   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube
   feeds until this has improved
   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   .
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain
   regimen when sedation decreased
   - follow gastroenterology recommendations
   .
   Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild iron
   deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.  Currently
   26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   .
   COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers of xopenex and ipratropium
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
   .
   Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   .
   FEN: NPO, IVF for above parameters, nutrition consult, replete
   electrolytes
   .
   Prophylaxis: SC  heparin
   .
   Code: Full code
   .

   .

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated medical history, including esophagectomy, COPD, and atrial arrhythmia. She was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress, recurrent coffee ground emesis, and melena. The patient underwent intubation and subclavian line placement but developed a pneumothorax. She is currently on pressors and has a chest tube in place for the pneumothorax. Her vital signs are stable, but she has significant changes in her ECG, indicating demand ischemia in the RCA and LAD territories. She also has gastroparesis, nausea, and malnutrition, with ongoing dark material being suctioned from her NG tube. There are concerns about chronic abdominal pain, chronic blood loss anemia, COPD exacerbation, and chronic back pain with compression fractures. The patient is receiving multiple medications and has multiple lines and tubes in place.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to aspiration and mucus plugging in the setting of severe background lung disease (COPD). She is receiving mechanical ventilation support, and measures are being taken to prevent further aspiration.
2. Shock: The patient may have septic or hypovolemic shock, as indicated by low CVP and hypotension. It is important to continue with Levophed and work towards weaning off pressors while ensuring adequate volume repletion.
3.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old woman with a history of COPD and esophagectomy, admitted 40 days ago for malnutrition. She experienced acute respiratory distress and was intubated emergently. The patient had a pneumothorax, which required a chest tube placement, and was started on pressors. Overnight, there were EKG changes with anterolateral T wave inversions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 106 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 112/48 to 154/141 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 96%. The patient is receiving multiple medications including norepinephrine, midazolam, fentanyl, and heparin. The physical examination reveals clear breath sounds, absent pulses in both lower extremities, and warm skin. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and normal electrolyte levels. The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and there is a concern for aspiration pneumonia. The assessment includes respiratory failure, potential COPD exacerbation, hot nephrology consultation, and ongoing cardiac evaluation. The plan involves continuing current ventilator settings, antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia, and managing COPD symptoms. Additionally, the patient will need an arterial line due to unreliable blood pressures, and there is a suspicion of congestive heart failure. Sedation and agitation management are also part of the plan

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old woman with a history of COPD and esophagectomy. She was admitted 40 days ago for malnutrition and experienced acute respiratory distress yesterday, leading to intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with a pneumothorax, for which a chest tube was placed, and she has been started on pressors. There are also EKG changes showing anterolateral T wave inversions, indicating potential cardiac issues.    Assessment and Plan
   Assessment/Plan: 66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal
   perforation s/p esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to
   the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   Acute Respiratory Failure:  Both hypercarbic and hypoxic.  Patient
   initially suctioned with retrieval of large mucous plug but
   subsequently started vomiting with inability to protect airway
   requiring emergent intubation.  Suspect respiratory failure is
   multifactorial relating to patient's underlying severe emphysema,
   mucous plugging and possible pneumonia.  Pulmonary embolism and cardiac
   ischemic also considered given respiratory failure and hypotension
   although would expect CVP to be elevated in these settings and clinical
   picture more consistent with other etiologies.
   - start vancomycin and zosyn for hospital acquired pneumonia
   - xopenex and ipratropium nebulizers
   - deep suctioning if possible
   - will send sputum sample
   - blood and urine culures pending
   - repeat CXR in AM
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   Shock:  Patient became acutely hypotensive upon arrival to the MICU.
   Occurred in the setting of initiating sedating medications and
   intubation.  Also occurred in the setting of mucous plugging, rising
   white blood cell count and concern for aspiration.  CVP is low which
   would be consistent with either hypovolemic shock, decreased preload
   from medications and effects of positive pressure ventilation, and
   septic shock.  Cardiac and obstructive etiologies also considered given
   EKG changes but for now clinical picture appears more consistent
   infection vs. decreased preload.
   - IVF fluid boluses to maintain CVP 10-12, urine output 30cc/hr and SBP
   > 90
   - Levophed to maintain above paremeters
   - Repeat EKG
   - Rule out for myocardial infarction with serial cardiac enzymes
   - Vancomycin and Zosyn to cover for hospital acquired pneumonia
   - Repeat CXR in AM to assess size of pneumothorax
   - Attempt to limit use of midazolam since patient's blood pressures
   seem particularly sensitive to this [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - echocardiogram in AM
   Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak present.
   - chest tube to suction
   - serial CXR
   Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 100s.
   - continue digoxin
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension
   EKG changes:  Diffuse T wave inversions in inferior and anterior
   distribution.  Most likely related to demand ischemia in RCA and LAD
   territory.  Pulmonary embolism considered but would be less likely to
   cause strain in both arterial territories.  Diffuse changes also less
   consistent with myocardial infarction.
   - repeat EKG after improvement in hemodynamics
   - cycle cardiac enzymes
   - echocardiogram in AM
   Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding
   - active type and cross

   - currently with significant black material being suctioned from
   stomach so unlikely will be able to administer PO medications or tube

   - currently holding j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   Chronic Abdominal Pain:  Likely related to gastritis.  Also concern
   that G-J tube may have possible leak.  Being followed by GI consult
   service.  She has had many upper endoscopies and suboptimal
   colonoscopies.  Plans is currently for optomizing her nutritional
   status and ultimately rehab.
   - currently on fentanyl for sedation, will have to reassess pain

   - follow gastroenterology recommendations

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 45-year-old male admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure.
- The patient has a history of codeine allergy, which caused hives.
- The patient's arterial line was started on 10/18/2142 at 09:30 AM.
- During the trans thoracic echo, the patient experienced an episode of tachycardia to 200s, hypotension, and agitation, likely secondary to a bolus of sedatives. The symptoms improved with a 1L fluid bolus and adjustment of levophed.
- The patient's tracheostomy (PS) did not do well yesterday, so he will not be weaned at this time.
- The patient's left arterial line was placed.
- The patient's NGT output is guaiac negative, but stool is guaiac positive.
- The patient's urine culture is positive for E.coli, with preliminary sensitivities pending.
- The patient's nutrition recommendations include restarting the Jtube feeds and keeping the NG on suction.
- The patient attempted pressure support (PS) but experienced apnea for over 30 seconds, so he was put back on previous settings.
- The patient's right hand appears swollen.
- The patient is on multiple infusions including midazolam, fentanyl, and norepinephrine.
- The patient is also on heparin sodium prophylaxis.
- The patient's medical and family

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female who was admitted with respiratory failure and is likely experiencing aspiration events and mucus plugging. She has a history of esophagectomy and initially had complications with the placement of a subclavian vein catheter due to pneumothorax. The patient's hemodynamics have shown some improvement, but she still requires pressor support.

The assessment and plan include the following:

1) Respiratory Failure:
   - The primary hypoxemia persists, but ventilation is controlled with adequate ventilation.
   - Pneumothorax has resolved, and there is no air leak observed.
   - The source of persistent hypoxemic respiratory failure may be multi-factorial, including potential left-sided collapse, underlying pulmonary disease with significant emphysema and ineffective V/Q with significant apical dead space, or PE.

2) COPD with acute exacerbation:
   - Continue with bronchodilators.
   - Continue with ABX for pulmonary infection and sepsis.

3) Sepsis-Likely from pulmonary source:
   - Continue antibiotics.
   - Wean pressors.
   - Keep CVP=12 as goal.

4) Pneumothorax:
   - Move to water seal today.
   - Repeat CXR to evaluate PTX.
   - Will continue to discuss with surgery as to timing of removal but would favor maintenance while PPV is in place.

5) Atrial Tachycardia:
   - L

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated gastrointestinal history who underwent an esophagectomy and is now admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. She has a history of COPD, severe gastroparesis, and emphysema. The patient was transferred from another hospital due to aspiration pneumonia and possible mucus plugging.

The patient's recent events include an ultrasound that showed no evidence of right heart strain or pulmonary embolism. She had a central line inserted but developed erythema and possible pus, so it was removed. The patient required fluid boluses for hypotension and has been receiving IV fluids. She also received antibiotics for aspiration coverage.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate in the 90s, blood pressure around 90/50 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 97%. The patient is sedated and intubated.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 17.5 K/uL, slightly elevated creatinine level, and normal liver function tests. The patient has a history of chronic blood loss anemia with a baseline hematocrit of 30-35, currently at 26.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient has multiple medical complications including acute respiratory failure, shock, tension pneumothorax (resolved), gastroparesis, multifocal atrial tachycardia

Close monitoring of the patient's oxygen requirements and response to treatment is essential.

3. Shock: The patient is showing signs of shock, likely secondary to the pneumonia and hypotension. Continuous fluid boluses are being administered to maintain a target central venous pressure (CVP) of 10-12. Close monitoring of the patient's blood

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female admitted with respiratory failure and likely aspiration event. She had an esophagectomy and initial emergent placement of a subclavian central venous catheter, which was complicated by pneumothorax that resolved with CT placement. The patient is currently off pressors and febrile with a temperature of 101.4°F. She has a urine culture showing gentamicin-sensitive E. coli, and sputum culture 3+ GNR. The patient's allergies include codeine, for which she experiences hives. The last doses of antibiotics were piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin on 10/20/2142 at 06:00 AM and 08:30 AM respectively. The patient is intubated and unable to provide history. 

Key Points:
- The patient had a pneumothorax that was resolved with CT placement.
- Septic shock due to pulmonary and urinary tract infections is present.
- A new central line will be placed, and the right subclavian line will be removed.
- Plans for extubation are being made for next week.
- The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and not requiring high FiO2.
- The patient has severe malnutrition and inadequate nutrition through the J-tube.
- TPN will be considered after reviewing the tube feed history.
- The patient's chest tube removal was meant to be mentioned

The plan is to remove the right SCL and place a new central line today.

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and not requiring high FiO2. The patient also has severe malnutrition as indicated by a J-tube that is not providing goal nutrition. Consideration will be given to total parenteral nutrition (TPN) after reviewing the tube feed history.

   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Known COPD and emphysema exacerbated by
   aspiration pneumonia. Inititally question of mucus plugging as well.
   She currently has a small, stable R sided PTX [**3-3**] subclavian line
   placement. Patient continued to be vented, without changes in setting
   overnight secondary to not being able to protect airway, thick
   secretions, and hypoxia.  Sputum today with 3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast
   suggestive of aspiration PNA, and likely covered by gentamycin, zosyn
   and vancomycin.
   -Continue vancomycin/Zosyn  for aspiration coverage
   -F/u culture data
   -treid to measure dead space ventilation but no CO2 equivalent in this
   campus, didnt' happen yesterday
   -Repeat CXR in AM
   - change nebs to standing
   Shock: Patient with pneumonia and hypotension in the setting of
   sedation, mediactions and possibly transient bacteremia. CVP is better
   with boluses. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and moderate pulmonary
   hypertension.
   -Continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12
   - will speciate enterobacter in urine
    Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  No air leak present now.
   - chest tube to water seal yesterday, repeat chest x-ray without
   evidence of pneumothorax
   - serial CXR
   Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 100s.
   - continue digoxin
   - holding metoprolol given hypotension
    Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Currently with dark black material
   in NGT which is hemoccult negative.  Per hospitalist on floor, this
   likely is related to bannana flakes in patient's tube feeds.  On floor
   patient continued to have severe nausea and vomiting in relation to any
   PO intake.  Gastric emptying study showed 0% emptying at 4 hours.
   - serial hematocrits given concern initially for GI bleeding however
   guaic negative with stable crit
   - currently intubated, sedated- currently with significant black
   material being suctioned from stomach so unlikely will be able to
   administer PO medications or tube feeds until this has improved
   - currently on j-tube feeds
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
    Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 26 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
    COPD: Severe emphysema on imaging.  Likely contributing to her
   respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats > 90%
    Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned

She also has multifocal atrial tachycardia, gastroparesis, chronic blood loss anemia, severe emphysema, and chronic back pain with compression fractures. The patient is currently receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, sedatives, and pain management.

2. Pneumothorax recurrence: Although the current right-sided pneumothorax has been stabilized, there is still a risk of recurrence due to the patient's underlying lung disease and potential for further barotrauma.
3. Shock: The patient's hypotension and low cardiac output indicate ongoing shock. Close monitoring of vital signs and fluid balance will be essential to ensure adequate perfusion.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD and emphysema, who underwent esophagectomy and developed severe gastroparesis. She was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has several medical complications including hypoxic respiratory failure, shock (likely urosepsis), tension pneumothorax, multifocal atrial tachycardia, gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition, chronic blood loss anemia, COPD exacerbation, and chronic back pain with compression fractures.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.6°C (101.4°F), heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure of 121/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on mechanical ventilation. The patient is sedated and intubated.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and normal platelet count. Other lab values such as creatinine, troponin T, glucose, and electrolytes are within normal limits. Imaging studies reveal a small, stable right-sided pleural effusion and good re-expansion on chest X-ray after decompression and chest tube placement.

The patient's medical plan includes continuing vancomycin and Zosyn for aspiration coverage, speciating GNR in sputum and adjusting coverage as needed, continuing fluid boluses

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 45-year-old male admitted to the ICU with symptoms of fever, hypotension, and septic shock. The patient has a history of E. coli and Enterococcus infection in the urine, as well as GNR-positive sputum culture. The patient is currently receiving antibiotics (gentamicin, piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin) for the infections. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 121/62 mmHg to 123/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is also receiving nutritional support through enteral feeding.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Known COPD and emphysema exacerbated by
   aspiration pneumonia. Inititally question of mucus plugging as well.
   She currently has a small, stable R sided PTX [**3-3**] subclavian line
   placement.  Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast suggestive of
   aspiration PNA, and likely covered by zosyn and vancomycin.  Patient
   now on pressure support [**11-4**] with FiO2 of 50%. She is moving ~350cc and
   RR 15 with those settings. Patient almost at baseline mental status,
   diminished gag reflex, normal secretions, but got very agitated,
   tachycardic, hypertensive and desated when tried to be weaned. Now on
   Haldol standing plus zyprexa PRN.
   - Continue vancomycin/Zosyn  for aspiration coverage (day 2 and 5
   respectively)
   - F/u culture data
   - attempt to wean sedation and decrease FiO2; may be candidate for
   extubation later today.
   - Keep chest tube for today, since there is still PTX on CXR
   # Agitation: Patient became agitated when tried to be weaned of vent.
   -          Continue haldol PRN
   -          Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Shock: Patient in shock likely [**3-3**] urosepsis & PNA all involving GRN
   for which she is receiving zosyn. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and
   moderate pulmonary hypertension.
   - continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12
   - speciate GNR in sputum and adjust coverage as needed
   - vanco/zosyn (day 2 and 5 respectively)
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak noted today while pt on water
   seal yesterday. Put back on low suction, will follow final read of CXR
   and if no pneumo will try again to put on water seal.
   - chest tube to low suction
   - check CXR this PM
   - f/u thoracic recs
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 80s.
   - continue digoxin
   - can restart metoprolol today
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  There is question whether or not
   patient is absorbing her TF. Residuals have been minimal which is
   promising however it is possible she has bowel edema that prevents her
   from absorbing nutrients, causing her malnutrition. Patient absorbed
   tylenol, so there is some degree of absorption. Will continue TF for
   now.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 23 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration,
   however her hct has trended down since admission. Has been guaiac + but
   this has been her baseline and there is question whether this is caused
   by irritation at the J-tube site. Will transfuse as needed for now if
   needed; she is hemodynamically stable.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   # FEN: TF for now, IVF for above parameters, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI
   # Code: Full code
   # Communication: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 849**] Daughter [**Known firstname 341**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 850**].  Alternate is
   son [**Telephone/Fax (1) 851**].
   # Lines : RIJ, PIV
   # Disposition: ICU care for now

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, who has been admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure.
- She underwent an esophagectomy and developed severe gastroparesis, which led to the aspiration of food into her lungs.
- The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation with pressure support (PS) and supplemental oxygen (FiO2 of 50%).
- She has a small, stable right-sided pleural effusion (PTX) and a subclavian line in place.
- Sputum culture results show the presence of GNR (Gram-negative rods) and budding yeast, indicating aspiration pneumonia.
- The patient's mental status is almost back to baseline, but she becomes agitated, tachycardic, and hypertensive when attempting to be weaned from sedation.
- She is being treated with vancomycin and Zosyn for aspiration coverage, and her sedation is being managed with Haldol and Seroquel.
- The patient also has evidence of urosepsis and PNA involving GNR, for which she is receiving Zosyn.
- Her echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction (EF) greater than 55% and moderate pulmonary hypertension.
- The patient's chest tube has been placed to relieve tension pneumothorax, and she has good re-expansion on chest X-ray (CXR).

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Known COPD and emphysema exacerbated by
   aspiration pneumonia. Inititally question of mucus plugging as well.
   She currently has a small, stable R sided PTX [**3-3**] subclavian line
   placement.  Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast suggestive of
   aspiration PNA, and likely covered by zosyn and vancomycin.  Patient
   now on pressure support [**11-4**] with FiO2 of 50%. She is moving ~350cc and
   RR 15 with those settings. Patient almost at baseline mental status,
   diminished gag reflex, normal secretions, but got very agitated,
   tachycardic, hypertensive and desated when tried to be weaned. Now on
   Haldol standing plus zyprexa PRN.
   - Continue vancomycin/Zosyn  for aspiration coverage (day 2 and 5
   respectively)
   - F/u culture data
   - attempt to wean sedation and decrease FiO2; may be candidate for
   extubation later today.
   - Keep chest tube for today, since there is still PTX on CXR
   # Agitation: Patient became agitated when tried to be weaned of vent.
   -          Continue haldol PRN
   -          Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Shock: Patient in shock likely [**3-3**] urosepsis & PNA all involving GRN
   for which she is receiving zosyn. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and
   moderate pulmonary hypertension.
   - continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12
   - speciate GNR in sputum and adjust coverage as needed
   - vanco/zosyn (day 2 and 5 respectively)
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak noted today while pt on water
   seal yesterday. Put back on low suction, will follow final read of CXR
   and if no pneumo will try again to put on water seal.
   - chest tube to low suction
   - check CXR this PM
   - f/u thoracic recs
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 80s.
   - continue digoxin
   - can restart metoprolol today
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  There is question whether or not
   patient is absorbing her TF. Residuals have been minimal which is
   promising however it is possible she has bowel edema that prevents her
   from absorbing nutrients, causing her malnutrition. Patient absorbed
   tylenol, so there is some degree of absorption. Will continue TF for
   now.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 23 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration,
   however her hct has trended down since admission. Has been guaiac + but
   this has been her baseline and there is question whether this is caused
   by irritation at the J-tube site. Will transfuse as needed for now if
   needed; she is hemodynamically stable.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   # FEN: TF for now, IVF for above parameters, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, emphysema, and recent esophagectomy who presented with acute respiratory failure. She required intubation and mechanical ventilation. The patient has been diagnosed with aspiration pneumonia, a small stable right-sided pleural effusion, and tension pneumothorax, which has been decompressed and a chest tube placed. She also has multifocal atrial tachycardia, gastroparesis, chronic blood loss anemia, and severe emphysema contributing to her respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's known COPD and emphysema, exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia, continue to cause hypoxic respiratory failure.
2. Tension pneumothorax: The patient had a tension pneumothorax, which has been decompressed and a chest tube placed. However, there is still a small pleural effusion present, and there may be ongoing air leaks.
3. Shock: The patient is in shock likely due to urosepsis and pneumonia involving gram-negative rods (GNR) for which she is receiving zosyn. Echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction >55% and moderate pulmonary hypertension.
4. Agitation: The patient became agitated when tried to be weaned off the ventilator. She is currently on haloperidol and quetiapine for agitation.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of gastroparesis, esophagectomy, and significant COPD.
- She was admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to aspiration and superinfection with Gram-negative rods (GNR's).
- The patient has shown some capacity to tolerate pressure support ventilation (PSV) but still requires significant ventilatory support.
- She has a chest tube with minimal drainage but persistent air leak.
- The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) below 105 this morning.
- She will be undergoing a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) after 60 minutes with 7 liters of oxygen, and her ABG will be checked at that time.
- Current medications include vancomycin, gentamicin, piperacillin/tazobactam, atrovent, and heparin sodium.
- The plan is to wean sedation this morning and trial extubation later today based on the response to SBT.
- The patient also has pneumonia, which is being treated with vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.
- A pneumothorax has been identified, and the chest tube is currently on water seal due to a one-chamber leak.
- The patient's agitation is being managed with haloperidol and olanzapine.
- Nutritional support includes a pulmonary

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration
   pneumonia. Also with R sided stable PTX .  Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+
   budding yeast c/w aspiration PNA, covered by zosyn and vancomycin.
   Continues on PS. Did not do well with SBT and continues to have
   moderate thick secretions. It is unlikely SBT failed d/t agitation as
   before since she was pretreated w/haldol.
   - F/u speciation on culture data
   - attempt to wean sedation and decrease FiO2.
   - Follow PTX on CXR, to water seal if leak stopped
   # Agitation: Improved w/haldol, seroquel.
   -          Continue haldol PRN
   -          Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Shock: Patient in shock likely [**3-3**] urosepsis & gram negative
   aspiration PNA. Echocardiogram with EF >55% and moderate pulmonary
   hypertension.
   - continue fluid boluses; goal CVP 10-12 and adequate UOP
   - speciate GNR in sputum and adjust coverage as needed
   - vanco/zosyn (day 3 and 6 respectively)
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Now s/p decompression and chest tube placement
   with good re-expansion on CXR.  Air leak noted on low suction, will
   follow final read of CXR and if no pneumo will try again to put on
   water seal.
   - chest tube to low suction
   - check CXR this PM
   - f/u thoracic recs
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 70s,
   improved with restarting metoprolol.
   - continue digoxin
   - continue metoprolol
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Patient has been shown to be
   absorbing via TF thus will continue with adjustments per nutrition
   recommendations. Follow residuals.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Previously in this admission with mild
   iron deficiency and chronic disease.  Baseline hematocrit 30-35.
   Currently 23 in the setting of significant IV fluid administration,
   however her hct has trended down since admission. Has been guaiac + but
   this has been her baseline and there is question whether this is caused
   by irritation at the J-tube site. Will transfuse as needed for now if
   needed; she is hemodynamically stable.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   - active type and screen
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty.
   - continue fentanyl for sedation
   - reassess pain regimen once medications weaned
   # FEN: TF, IVF, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, who was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. She has undergone an esophagectomy and is now presenting with severe gastroparesis. The patient was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure, which was exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. She also has a right-sided stable pneumothorax and is on water seal. Sputum cultures show 3+ GNR and 2+ budding yeast, indicating aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's agitation has improved with the use of Haldol and Seroquel. She is currently in shock, likely due to urosepsis and gram-negative aspiration pneumonia. An echocardiogram shows an ejection fraction >55% and moderate pulmonary hypertension.

The patient had a tension pneumothorax, which has been decompressed and a chest tube placed. The chest tube is currently on water seal, and further evaluation will be done on a chest X-ray.

The patient is also experiencing multifocal atrial tachycardia, which has improved with the restarting of metoprolol. She has a history of gastroparesis, nausea, and malnutrition. The patient is absorbing nutrients through the transgastric route and will continue with adjustments in nutrition recommendations. Follow-up with nutrition recommendations is advised.

The patient's chronic blood loss anemia is stable, and initial concerns for a GI bleed have been ruled out

   perforation and now admit to ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure and

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD who underwent an esophagectomy due to perforation. She was admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure and had difficulty weaning from ventilatory support. The patient's condition has been complicated by a pneumothorax and hypotension. She has been on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, FiO2 of 50%, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. Her current vital signs include a heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure of 116/38 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98%. She has been receiving various medications including fentanyl, midazolam, heparin, pantoprazole, and vancomycin/Zosyn. The patient's labs show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 18.4 K/uL and elevated troponin T levels at 0.05 ng/mL. Imaging reveals a mild decrease in pulmonary opacities on chest X-ray. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's persistent difficulty weaning from ventilatory support suggests ongoing respiratory failure. Factors contributing to this may include dynamic hyperinflation, airflow obstruction due to COPD, pulmonary edema, and chest wall mechanics restriction.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration
   pneumonia. Also with R sided stable PTX on water seal..  Sputum with
   3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast c/w aspiration PNA now growing ESBL
   kleibsiella, moderate sensitive to zosyn; also on vancomycin. Extubated
   yesterday; doing well on 2 L NC. Afebrile; VS stable. Unchanged CXR.
   - Patient improving on Zosyn; if decompensates will start meropenem
   (day [**5-8**] of Vancomuycin and Zosyn respectively)
   - F/u remaining cultures.
   # Agitation: Improved w/haldol, seroquel.
   -Continue haldol PRN
   -Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Chest tube on water seal without any drainage
   or air leak. Will be pulled out today by IP.
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 70s,
   improved with metoprolol. Increased dose yesterday sisnce she was
   tachycardic.
   - continue digoxin
   - continue metoprolol, increase if BP tolerates
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Patient has been shown to be
   absorbing via TF thus will continue with adjustments per nutrition
   recommendations. Follow residuals.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Stable over last couple of days.
   Initially concern for GI bleed given positive guaiacs but apparently
   this is a baseline issue, potentially d/t irritation at Jtube site.
   Will continue to monitor on labs.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty. Patient put back on her home regimen.
   - continue fentanyl patch and liquid morphine per [**Hospital1 1023**].
   # FEN: TF, IVF, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI
   # Code: Full code

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, who was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure. She had undergone an esophagectomy and developed severe gastroparesis. The patient was intubated due to hypoxic respiratory failure caused by severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. She also had a right-sided tension pneumothorax, which has been treated with chest tube placement and is now on water seal. The patient's sputum culture showed ESBL Klebsiella, for which she is receiving treatment with Zosyn (moderate sensitivity). She is also on vancomycin. The patient's vital signs are stable, and she is improving on non-invasive ventilation. She has a history of agitation, which has improved with haloperidol and quetiapine. The patient's nutritional status is a concern due to gastroparesis, but she is absorbing nutrients through total parenteral nutrition (TF). She has chronic anemia due to chronic blood loss, possibly from irritation at the J-tube site. She has severe emphysema and is receiving nebulizers and oxygen therapy. The patient has multiple thoracic compression fractures with chronic back pain. She is on a fentanyl patch and liquid morphine for pain management. The patient's electrolytes are replete, and she is on prophylactic heparin and PPI. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure

   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration
   pneumonia. Also with R sided stable PTX on water seal..  Sputum with
   3+GNR and 2+ budding yeast c/w aspiration PNA now growing ESBL
   kleibsiella, moderate sensitive to zosyn; also on vancomycin. Extubated
   yesterday; doing well on 2 L NC. Afebrile; VS stable. Unchanged CXR.
   - Patient improving on Zosyn; if decompensates will start meropenem
   (day [**5-8**] of Vancomuycin and Zosyn respectively)
   - F/u remaining cultures.
   # Agitation: Improved w/haldol, seroquel.
   -Continue haldol PRN
   -Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Chest tube on water seal without any drainage
   or air leak. Will be pulled out today by IP.
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 70s,
   improved with metoprolol. Increased dose yesterday sisnce she was
   tachycardic.
   - continue digoxin
   - continue metoprolol, increase if BP tolerates
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Patient has been shown to be
   absorbing via TF thus will continue with adjustments per nutrition
   recommendations. Follow residuals.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Stable over last couple of days.
   Initially concern for GI bleed given positive guaiacs but apparently
   this is a baseline issue, potentially d/t irritation at Jtube site.
   Will continue to monitor on labs.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty. Patient put back on her home regimen.
   - continue fentanyl patch and liquid morphine per [**Hospital1 1023**].
   # FEN: TF, IVF, replete electrolytes

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. She underwent an esophagectomy and developed severe gastroparesis. The patient also has a right-sided tension pneumothorax that is being managed with chest tube drainage. She has been experiencing agitation, which has improved with the use of antipsychotic medications. The patient also has multifocal atrial tachycardia, which is being managed with digoxin and metoprolol. She has gastroparesis and malnutrition, for which nutrition recommendations are being followed. The patient's chronic blood loss anemia is stable, and she has severe emphysema contributing to her respiratory failure. She also has chronic back pain with compression fractures. The patient's electrolytes are being monitored, and she is receiving prophylactic heparin and PPI. Code status is full code.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure due to severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia.
2. Tension pneumothorax on the right side.
3. Multifocal atrial tachycardia.
4. Gastroparesis and malnutrition.
5. Chronic blood loss anemia.
6. Severe emphysema contributing to respiratory failure.
7. Chronic back pain with compression fractures.

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD who was admitted with acute respiratory failure. She had an invasive ventilation, but was successfully extubated without any events. The patient has shown improvement over time and is currently on 2 lpm O2 supplementation. She also has evidence of a significant bacterial infection, likely Klebsiella pneumoniae, for which Vancomycin and Zosyn are being continued. The patient's current plan includes ambulating, using incentive spirometry, and maintaining a negative fluid balance. She also has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, a resolved pneumothorax, and chronic pain, for which Dilaudid and a fentanyl patch are being used.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure could worsen if she experiences further complications such as pneumonia or mucus plugging.
2. Hospital-Acquired Infection: The patient is at risk for acquiring additional infections, particularly given her prolonged ICU stay and invasive procedures.
3. Enterococcal UTI: The presence of an enterococcal urinary tract infection may require consideration of discontinuing Vancomycin.
4. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) Exacerbation: The patient's underlying COPD could exacerbate, leading to further respiratory distress.
5. Pneumothorax Recurrence: Although the current pneumothorax appears to be resolved, there is a risk

The patient is a 55-year-old male admitted to the ICU with complaints of shortness of breath (SOB). The patient has undergone several medical interventions, including invasive ventilation, pneumothorax, and chest tube placement. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 132/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 350 mL, respiratory rate set at 14, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, FiO2 of 60%, and RSBI of 150.

The patient's physical examination reveals no acute distress, thin appearance, anxious expression, pale conjunctiva, normocephalic head, endotracheal tube in place, symmetric chest expansion, resonant percussion, rhonchorous breath sounds, presence of fluid on chest auscultation, soft abdomen with bowel sounds, warm skin, attentive mental status, purposeful movements, and normal muscle tone.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.1 K/uL, hemoglobin level of 7.7 g/dL, sodium level of 72 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.8 mEq/L, creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL, and blood glucose level of 86 mg/dL. Other lab values

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, who was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. She had undergone an esophagectomy and developed severe gastroparesis. The patient also has chronic back pain with compression fractures and chronic blood loss anemia.

Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's severe COPD was exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. She also had a right-sided stable pneumothorax, which was drained but with minimal fluid output.
2. Tension pneumothorax: The patient's chest tube was placed on suction without air leak or drainage, and it will be changed to water seal today. There is a consideration for pleurodesis due to the failed attempt at removing the chest tube.
3. Multifocal atrial tachycardia: The patient's heart rate improved with metoprolol, but she continues to have episodes of tachycardia. Digoxin and increased doses of metoprolol are being continued.
4. Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition: The patient has been shown to be absorbing nutrients through the transverse colon, so adjustments to nutrition recommendations are being made. Residuals will be monitored.
5. Chronic blood loss anemia: The patient initially had a concern for GI bleed, but this appears to be a baseline issue potentially due to irritation at the Jtube site.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD who presented with acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has undergone an esophagectomy and has severe gastroparesis. The patient was transferred to the ICU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: Severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. She also has a right-sided stable pneumothorax and has had a chest tube placed. The patient's sputum culture showed growth of ESBL Klebsiella, which is moderately sensitive to Zosyn. She is currently on vancomycin as well.

2. Agitation: The patient's agitation has improved with the use of haloperidol and quetiapine. It is recommended to continue these medications on an as-needed basis.

3. Tension pneumothorax: The patient's chest tube is currently on suction without air leak or drainage. It is planned to change it to water seal today. Considering the failed attempt at removal, pleurodesis may be considered.

4. Multifocal atrial tachycardia: The patient's heart rate is currently in the 70s and has improved with metoprolol. The dose of metoprolol should be increased if the patient's blood pressure tolerates it. Continuing with digoxin is also recommended.

5. Gastroparesis/na

2. Pneumothorax: The patient has a pneumothorax, which can cause collapsed lung and difficulty in breathing. If left untreated or if the chest tube becomes dislodged, the pneumothorax can recur, leading to repeated episodes of respiratory failure.

3. Gastroparesis: The patient has gastric ileus, which indicates delayed emptying of the stomach contents. This can increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia and other complications related to poor gastrointestinal motility.

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. She also has a right-sided stable pneumothorax that is being treated with chest tube drainage.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated gastrointestinal history post esophagectomy, advanced chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and recent pneumothorax due to right subclavian insertion. She was transferred from the floor with acute respiratory distress and required emergent intubation. The patient's condition has been unstable, with multiple episodes of increased fentanyl and pain control, possible laryngeal edema, wheezing, and tons of secretions. She had labored breathing, hypoxia, and hypercarbia, necessitating reintubation with the tube pulled out 2cm from its original position.

The patient has allergies to codeine, which causes hives, and has received various antibiotics, including vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), and piperacillin alone. She is currently on infusions of fentanyl and midazolam (Versed). Other ICU medications include hydromorphone (Dilaudid) and heparin sodium for prophylaxis.

The patient's medical and family history remains unchanged except for the recent events. Review of systems is also unchanged from admission.

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration
   pneumonia. Also with R sided stable PTX on suction for post-pulling
   chest tube. Drained 10cc in 24 hours. Sputum with 3+GNR and 2+ budding
   yeast c/w aspiration PNA now growing ESBL kleibsiella, moderate
   sensitive to zosyn; also on vancomycin. Extubated yesterday; doing well
   on 2 L NC. Afebrile; VS stable. Unchanged CXR.
   - Switch to Pressure support [**11-4**] and ABGs afterwards
   - Patient improving on Zosyn; if decompensates will start meropenem
   (day [**6-7**])
   - F/u remaining cultures.
   # Agitation: Improved w/haldol, seroquel.
   -Continue haldol PRN
   -Continue Quetitapine PRN
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Chest tube on suction without air leak or
   drainage. Will change it to water seal today. We need to consider
   pleurodesis after prior failed attempt of removal.
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 70s,
   improved with metoprolol. Increased dose yesterday since she was
   tachycardic.
   - continue digoxin
   - continue metoprolol, increase if BP tolerates
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Patient has been shown to be
   absorbing via TF thus will continue with adjustments per nutrition
   recommendations. Follow residuals.
   - f/u nutrition recs
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Stable over last couple of days.
   Initially concern for GI bleed given positive guaiacs but apparently
   this is a baseline issue, potentially d/t irritation at Jtube site.
   Will continue to monitor on labs.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty. Patient put back on her home regimen.
   - continue fentanyl patch and liquid morphine per PEG.
   # FEN: TF, IVF, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI
   # Code: Full code
   # Communication: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 849**] Daughter [**Known firstname 341**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 850**].  Alternate is
   son [**Telephone/Fax (1) 851**].
   # Lines : RIJ, PIV
   # Disposition: Can go to the floor later today.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a complicated gastrointestinal history, including an esophagectomy, who was admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory distress requiring emergent intubation. The patient has advanced COPD and experienced a pneumothorax after the insertion of a right subclavian catheter.

The patient's medical history includes esophageal perforation following an esophagectomy, severe gastroparesis, chronic back pain with compression fractures, and chronic blood loss anemia. The patient has been treated for various complications, such as hypoxic respiratory failure due to severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia, tension pneumothorax, multifocal atrial tachycardia, gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition, chronic blood loss anemia, and chronic back pain/compression fractures.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.3 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 94 beats per minute, blood pressure of 122/57 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is sedated and responds to commands.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.1 thousand/mm3, hemoglobin level of 7.6 g/dL, creatinine level of 0.4 mg/dL, potassium level of 4.1 mEq/L, sodium level of 139 mEq/L, chloride level of 103 mEq/L, bicarbonate level of 24.8%, blood urea nitrogen level of 29 mg/dL, glucose level of 91 mg/dL, and platelet count of 484 thousand/mm3. Other lab values are within normal range.

The patient is currently on several medications, including fentanyl, midazolam, heparin sodium, and various antibiotics. The patient's nutritional needs are being met through total parenteral nutrition (TF).

Potential medical complications that can arise include further respiratory distress, infection due to prolonged intubation, development of pressure ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with severe chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD) experiencing recurrent acute exacerbations in the setting of chronic respiratory failure. The source of the chronic failure is her COPD. The patient has had multiple intubations due to pneumothorax and resulting tachypnea, dynamic hyperinflation, and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

The patient's current condition is acute respiratory failure, primarily hypoxemic. She will need pressure support ventilation (PSV) to continue and have continued support until new stability can be established. Specific interventions include:

1. Respiratory Failure-Acute-primarily hypoxemic at this time:
- PSV support until new stability is established.
- Pneumothorax: Chest tube to suction.
- COPD: Continue with PSV support and if extubation attempted, will need to extubate to non-invasive ventilation.
- Upper Airway Edema: Systemic steroids may be indicated due to likely COPD exacerbation.
- Pneumonia: Vancomycin/Meropenem for renewed coverage with concern for ventilatory associated pneumonia.
- If not favorable for extubation, consider tracheostomy for long-term support.
- If re-extubated, need to extubate to non-invasive ventilation.

2. Pneumothorax: Maintain suction.

3. Nutrition: Obtain GI access for feeds and attempt to place

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 66-year-old female with several medical conditions and complications. She has been admitted to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. The patient has a history of COPD, esophageal perforation post esophagectomy, and severe gastroparesis. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate of 77 bpm (normal range: 75-108 bpm), blood pressure of 114/49 mmHg (with a previous range of 65-150/44-90 mmHg), respiratory rate of 10 breaths per minute (normal range: 9-20 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including codeine, vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), piperacillin, meropenem, midazolam (Versed), fentanyl, and heparin sodium (prophylaxis). 

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) levels, decreased hemoglobin (Hct), and platelet count (Plt). The results also indicate abnormalities in creatinine (Cr), total carbon dioxide (TCO2), glucose, liver enzymes (ALT/AST), electrolytes (Na+/K+/Mg++/PO4), and other parameters.

The patient's chest X-ray shows right-sided stable pneumothorax (PTX) on suction for post-pulling chest tube. 

The patient's assessment and plan include several medical issues: hypoxic respiratory failure due to severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia, right-sided tension pneumothorax with chest tube on suction, agitation, multifocal atrial tachycardia, gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition, chronic blood loss anemia, severe emphysema contributing to respiratory failure, chronic back pain/compression fractures, total parenteral nutrition (TF), prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, tension pneumothorax leading to further respiratory compromise, development of antibiotic resistance due to prolonged antibiotic use, malnutrition due to gastroparesis and inability to eat normally, bleeding due to chronic blood loss anemia, and worsening of COPD symptoms.

Please note that the patient's condition may change over time, and it is crucial to closely monitor her progress and adjust the treatment plan accordingly.

   ------ Protected Section ------
   This evening, pt remains extubated, high FiO2 requirement, suctioned
   vigorously earlier in the day and less congested. Remains high risk for
   re-intubation. Will check ABG later tonight with initiation of NIPPV if
   developing hypercarbia or increased work of breathing.
   After extubation, pt voiced to RN her wish not to be further intubated
   or to undergo trach. Her family remains in conflict over this decision,
   with varying opinions for DNI vs. re-intubate vs. trach. Psych consult
   sought who stated that pt currently not capable of making her own
   decisions. She remains full code and will try to meet with family
   tomorrow.
   Pt remains critically ill.
   Additional 25 minutes spent.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 1174**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2142-10-27**] 22:12 ------
   Subsequently, pt developed worsening resp distress with increased work
   of breathing and hypercarbia on blood gas. Discussed NIPPV, but did not
   pursue due to secretions. Re-intubated. CXR post-intubation pending. Of
   note during earlier suctioning, bile contents recovered.
   Additional 20 minutes spent.
   ------ Protected Section Addendum Entered By:[**Name (NI) 1174**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **], MD
   on:[**2142-10-27**] 23:31 ------

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 66-year-old female with a history of COPD, esophageal perforation post esophagectomy, and severe gastroparesis. She was transferred to the ICU for acute respiratory failure requiring intubation. She has been diagnosed with hypoxic respiratory failure due to severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia. The patient also has a right-sided stable pneumothorax on suction and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient self-extubated this morning but required reintubation a few hours later. She is currently on a shovel mask and doing well. The plan is to continue meropenem (started yesterday), discuss the patient's goals regarding intubation/tracheostomy, and perform a psych evaluation to ensure she has the capacity to make decisions about her health.

The patient's agitation has improved with haldol and seroquel, but her anxiety and depression may not be adequately treated. There is conflict among the patient's family regarding the need for reintubation. A psych consult is planned.

The patient has a tension pneumothorax, for which a chest tube was placed on suction today. Follow-up with thoracic surgery regarding the plan for chest tube removal is needed.

The patient is experiencing multifocal atrial tachycardia, which has improved with metoprolol. Digoxin will be continued, and the metoprolol dose may be increased if her blood pressure tolerates it.

The patient has gastroparesis, nausea, and malnutrition. She is absorbing nutrients through the tube feeding (TF), so adjustments per nutrition recommendations will be made. Residuals will be monitored, and a nasogastric (NG) tube will not be pursued at this point.

The patient has chronic blood loss anemia, which is stable over the last couple of days. Initially, concern for GI bleed was raised due to positive guaiacs, but this may be a baseline issue, potentially due to irritation at the Jtube site. Serial hematocrits will be monitored, and a transfusion goal of less than 21 will be targeted.

The patient has severe emphysema at baseline, which is a significant contributor to her respiratory failure. Nebulizers will be continued, and oxygen will be titrated for saturation levels greater than 88-94%.

The patient also has chronic back pain and compression fractures in the thoracic region. Orthopedics has determined that kyphoplasty is not necessary. The patient will be put back on her home pain management regimen.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure due to severe COPD exacerbated by aspiration pneumonia.
2. Tension pneumothorax.
3. Multifocal atrial tachycardia.
4. Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition.
5. Chronic blood loss anemia.
6. Severe emphysema.
7. Chronic back pain/com

   Assessment and Plan
   66 year old female with COPD on 2L oxygen, esophageal perforation s/p
   esophagectomy and severe gastroparesis transferred to the [**Hospital Unit Name 4**] for
   acute respiratory failure requiring intubation.
   # Hypoxic respiratory failure:  Patient with severe COPD and possible
   aspiration PNA with recent left side iatrogenic PTX. She had 3 +GNR in
   sputum and 2+ budding yeasts and cultures with ESBL kleibsiella.
   Patient on day 3 of meropenem. Patient has required re-intubation 3
   times so far for multiple reasons. Patient with copious secretions,
   from GI tract and now very sedated.
   -          f/u cultures
   -          Continue meropenem (Day [**4-7**])
   -          Discuss goals of care with family; she qualifies for
   tracheostomy and possibly to pleurodesis. However, it would depend in
   what her wishes are. Right now she is delirious and unable to make a
   decision or understand the consequences of it.
   .
   # Agitation: Improved with haldol and seroquel. However, yesterday
   patient very delirious after she self-extuabted. Patient has multiple
   reasons to be delirious such as being in the ICU, PNA, intensive pain
   control regimen, etc. Right now will continue haldol and seroquel PRN.
   Seen by psychiatry yesterday
   -F/u psych recs
   -Continue haldol seroquel for now
   .
   # Tension Pneumothorax:  Patient with PTX after right subclavian line
   placement that required emergent needle decompression and posterior
   chest tube. Then, PTX recurred after chest tube was taken out. Now
   resolved on CXR, no leaking on the chest tube nor drainage in the last
   24 hours. However, she may be candidate for pleurodesis at this point.
   # Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia: Currently her rate is in the 70s,
   improved with metoprolol. Increased dose yesterday since she was
   tachycardic.
   - continue digoxin
   - continue metoprolol, increase if BP tolerates
   # Gastroparesis/nausea/malnutrition:  Patient has been shown to be
   absorbing via TF thus will continue with adjustments per nutrition
   recommendations. Follow residuals. Will not pursue NG tube at this
   point.
   - [**Hospital1 **] PPI
   - continue calcium, vitamin D
   # Chronic Blood Loss Anemia:  Stable over last couple of days.
   Initially concern for GI bleed given positive guaiacs but apparently
   this is a baseline issue, potentially d/t irritation at Jtube site.
   Will continue to monitor on labs.
   - serial hematocrits
   - transfusion goal < 21
   # COPD: Severe emphysema at baseline which is significant contributor
   of her respiratory failure.
   - continue nebulizers standing
   - titrate oxygen for sats >88-94%
   # Chronic Back Pain/Compression Fractures:  Patient with multiple
   thoracic compression fractures.  Per orthopedics no role for
   kyphoplasty. Patient put back on her home regimen.
   -          may need to rethink her pain medication as this is patients
   main complaint, will redoes her PO medications
   -          if not reintubated on sedation, continue fentanyl patch.
   # FEN: TF, replete electrolytes
   # Prophylaxis: SC  heparin, [**Hospital1 **], PPI
